item.title: [PI] Two extra warriors guild add ons!
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:4, topic:445158”]Let’s say you have an XML file:

<weapon>
     <name>dong</name>
     <id>4151</id>
     <attack-speed>5</attack-speed>
</weapon

and a class:

public class WeaponDef {

     public static HashMap<Integer, WeaponDef> definitions;

     static {
          definitions = new HashMap<Integer, WeaponDef>();
     }

     private int attackSpeed, id;
     private String name;

     public WeaponDef(String name, int attackSpeed, int id) {
          this.name = name;
          this.attackSpeed = attackSpeed;
          this.id = id;
          definitions.put(this.id, this);
     }

     //... getAttribute() methods below
}

You’d load the XML file on server start and construct WeaponDefs for each entry. This way, you could simply use WeaponDef.definitions.get(weponId) to retrieve any attributes the weapon has.[/quote]

Hmm, do you think it would be worth doing for something so small like this tutorial?

Read full topic
item.source: [PI] Two extra warriors guild add ons!

item.title: [PI] Two extra warriors guild add ons!
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Let’s say you have an XML file:

<weapon>
     <name>dong</name>
     <id>4151</id>
     <attack-speed>5</attack-speed>
</weapon

and a class:

public class WeaponDef {

     public static HashMap<Integer, WeaponDef> definitions;

     static {
          definitions = new HashMap<Integer, WeaponDef>();
     }

     private int attackSpeed, id;
     private String name;

     public WeaponDef(String name, int attackSpeed, int id) {
          this.name = name;
          this.attackSpeed = attackSpeed;
          this.id = id;
          definitions.put(this.id, this);
     }

     //... getAttribute() methods below
}

You’d load the XML file on server start and construct WeaponDefs for each entry. This way, you could simply use WeaponDef.definitions.get(weponId) to retrieve any attributes the weapon has.

Read full topic
item.source: [PI] Two extra warriors guild add ons!

item.title: [PI] Two extra warriors guild add ons!
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

t4:

having a crapton of cases in your switch statements is none too good. try using a markup language to organize the data and then place loaded data into encapsulated classes. this will greatly cut down on the number of lines in switchAttackType(Client c, int button) and greatly improve it’s re-usability.

Alright I appreciate the comment, I’ll try to redo it now.

Edit:

you mean like putting all the data into another class?

Read full topic
